Award.AwardTitle: A Distributed Coaxial Cable Strainmeter for Earth Monitoring
Award.AbstractNarration:
1442623
Wei

This grant supports development and testing of a distributed coaxial cable strainmeter that has the potential to offer high accuracy (~ ppm) and high temporal resolution (~1 sec) measurements with unprecedented high spatial (~ 10 m) resolution over kilometers. The concept will rely on tests of coaxial cables that have been imparted with periodic electromagnetic impedance discontinuities (a Bragg grating) which allow for weak reflections of a pulsed input of an electromagnetic wave through the coaxial waveguide or implanted reflectors within the coaxial cable that will enable a coaxial strainmeter based on Fabry-Perot interferometry. A vector network analyzer then is then used to analyze transmission and reflection spectra. The PI would also explore novel signal amplification techniques to reduce losses from returned EM pulses along longer lengths of cable with multiple sensors points along the length of the cable.

The potential of the coaxial cable based strainmeter to survive large deformations (5%) and strong lateral collision/impact, may provide valuable and otherwise inaccessible information under certain extreme conditions where fiber optic based strain technologies may fail (e.g., landslides, subglacial deformation, steel structure deformation). The development will engage a graduate student to assist with: 1) development of new modelling methodology for device design and optimization, 2) explore hybrid software-hardware signal processing technology; and 3) build a portable prototype coaxial strainmeter; and 4) characterize the prototype?s performance in the laboratory and in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The direct outcome of the proposed research is the fundamental understanding, implementation, and demonstration of the novel coaxial cable sensing concept, which combines large dynamic range, high precision, low-cost, and large multiplexing capacity to serve as a complementary tool for geodetic measurements under special scenarios, where sufficient robustness is required. Such a distributed sensor system has a great potential to advance geodetic observations to a new level. Potential applications include monitoring earthquake, landslide, volcano and glacial movements.This research consists of a number of key innovations as highlighted below:1) The innovative use of coaxial cable as the sensing platform provides a supreme robustness. This distinct advantage allows the new strainmeter to be employed in adverse conditions with large deformation and/or frequency impact/collision.2) The signal quality (SNR and intensity) of the cable sensing element is significantly enhanced by the novel looped coherent amplification technology.3) The novel hardware-based signal processing technology significantly increases the multiplexing capacity of the distributed cable sensing system. Thus, the equivalent cost of each of the sensing element drops accordingly.

This study will have a broad impact on geodic monitoring as it represents a leap in Earth observation technology. The successful completion of the project resulted in a transformative tool to answer a range of currently insufficiently-addressed questions in the area of earth science. A good example is that the proposed coaxial cable strainmeter can be deployed to monitor landslides, where low-cost, high spatial and temporal sampling of potentially large deformation is essential. Other important applications we envisioned include glacial movement, strain accumulation on the shallow part of offshore faults and subduction zones, and volcano hazard assessment and monitoring. In addition, this technology may find applications in structural health monitoring (SHM) of civil infrastructures, such as bridges, buildings, offshore platforms, and other man-made structures.Given the time and budget constraints, our efforts were focused on the design and demonstration of the new coaxial cable sensor for strain measurement. However, the fundamental knowledge of the device physics and the modeling/manufacturing/interrogation methodologies developed in this research are transferrable to the development of new cable sensors for other applications such as distributed monitoring of temperature, cracking and corrosion. In addition, the new sensor platform could be modified to measure chemical and biological species. These sensors may found many enabling applications beyond earth monitoring and SHM, such as pollution monitoring, environmental management and detection of chemical/biological warfare agents. As such, the fundamental studies may promise a broader societal impact on human welfare and national security.
